findings.title: Flashloan Attack
findings.description: When working with exchange rates, they should be received from a trusted source and not be vulnerable to short-term rate changes that can be achieved by using flash loans. Oracles should be used. Contracts shouldn’t rely on values that can be changed in the same transaction.

findings.title: Token Supply Manipulation
findings.description: Tokens can be minted only according to rules specified in a whitepaper or any other documentation provided by the Customer.

findings.title: Gas Limit and Loops
findings.description: Transaction execution costs should not depend dramatically on the amount of data stored on the contract. There should not be any cases when execution fails due to the block Gas limit.

findings.title: Style Guide Violation
findings.description: Contract readability and code quality are influenced significantly by adherence to established style guidelines.

findings.title: Requirements Compliance
findings.description: Functional requirements are provided. Technical description is provided: Technical specification is provided. NatSpec is sufficient.

findings.title: Secure Oracles Usage
findings.description: The code should have the ability to pause specific data feeds that it relies on. This should be done to protect a contract from compromised oracles.

findings.title: Tests Coverage
findings.description: Functions and state variables visibility should be set explicitly. Visibility levels should be specified consciously.

findings.title: H01. Highly Permissive Role Allows Access To Users Funds
findings.description: The Registrar role possesses extensive control over users' funds, allowing it to retrieve tokens from SmartCoin holders without their permission.

findings.title: L01. Missing Zero Address Validation
findings.description: Additional checks against the 0x0 address should be included in the reported functions to avoid unexpected results.

findings.title: L02. Multiple Roles Can Be Set For A Single Address
findings.description: Multiple roles can be set for a single address, potentially leading to unauthorized access or privilege escalation.

findings.title: I01. Style Guide Violation: Order Of Layout
findings.description: Contract readability and code quality are influenced significantly by adherence to established style guidelines.

findings.title: I02. Variable Shadowing as Improper Coding Standard
findings.description: The variable names registrar, operations, and technical in the SmartCoin constructor overshadow variables of the same name within the contract scope when inheriting from WhitelistUpgradeable.

findings.title: I03. Missing SPDX License Identifier
findings.description: Trust in smart contracts can be better established if their source code is available. Since making source code available always touches on legal problems with regard to copyright, the Solidity compiler encourages the use of machine-readable SPDX license identifiers.

findings.title: I04. Missing Initialization Calls To Parent Contracts
findings.description: The function initialize() does not call the initialize functions of its parent contracts __Whitelist_init() and __UUPSUpgradeable_init().

findings.title: I05. State Variables In Upgradeable Contracts Should Be In Initializer
findings.description: The contract WhitelistUpgradeable sets state variables registrar, operations and technical in the constructor instead of initializer, which can cause issues with upgradeable contracts.

findings.title: I06. EngagedAmount Collection Processing Lacks Consistency
findings.description: The engaged amount collection processing lacks consistency due to missing unchecked{} keyword in rejectTransfer() function.
